Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: A survey of big political ideas in history: Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes....
Reading the foundational texts of political philosophy, ranging from Plato to Rousseau, as well as contemporary works like DuBois was a lot of fun.

You learn a lot about government through this survey through political philosophers. You finally get to read some books which you know you should to be a well rounded individual. This is such an essential course to understanding how our government works and provides a more nuanced lens to read the news and evaluate politics today.

I mainly learned by reading the texts and thinking critically about them on my own. Unfortunately, the lecture and section were mediocre: at times I felt like I was back in a 9th grade level classroom. It is bizarre that such a thing would happen at Yale. Nonetheless, I am happy I learned what I did from reading the texts, many of which were fascinating.
I learned a lot about a variety of different concepts in Political Philosophy. The course was a good overview of the trajectory of Western political thought.

We read nearly every western political philosopher: Plato, Aristotle, Machiavelli, Hobbes, Rousseau, etc. It is called mini-DS for a reason. We focused on freedom, regime types, justice, and ended with more modern thinkers, such as Tocqueville and Du Bois, and their opinions on race in America.
I learned how to read texts rapidly and how to carry myself in a discussion section.
Basic understanding of works from the western canon. Did not help my writing at all
This class was extremely helpful in understanding why, at least in part, the US government looks why it does today.
Learned a lot about the path that political theory has taken over the millenia, and really got to see how intertwined all the main theories were.
This course guided me through lots of political philosophy reading that I really enjoyed. I learned a lot about the foundations of political thought.
I learned a lot about the philosophical foundation behind various systems of government. I also learned that I would like to further learn about these topics specially in the philosophical realm.
Survey knowledge of some important political philosophers
Learned a lot about political thought.
An historical overview of Political Philosophers
I think I gained a solid understanding of the foundational works in Western political philosophy and the analytical and writing skills to deeply examine their arguments.
Great survey of important readings, improved critical reading/analysis skills and writing skills. Great overall survey of different forms of government and their underlying philosophical foundations.
I learned about the philosophers that have helped shaped politics as we know it today while immensely improving my analytical writing.
Taught me the basics of political philosophy which was very helpful.

The class exposes you to many of the most important texts of political philosophy (see the syllabus to see the authors eg. Plato, Marx, Machiavelli). If you are interested in any way about political philosophy, and especially if you have not read these texts on your own, this course is deeply valuable. You get to be introduced to the texts, understand their main points and the contexts they were published in, and then to analyze a few parts in detail in section.
Think analytically about what I read and my own philosophies
Read some of the best texts of Western philosophy, grew my knowledge base of political thought and thinkers. Learned how to write a basic philosophy paper.
Basic knowledge of political philosophy history

I feel like this course helped me a great deal in developing my own use of reasoning and argumentation in my writing. I learned to become much more precise and accurate in my arguments while writing about philosophical topics in addition to learning a great deal about the foundations of western political philosophy and philosophy in general.
An appreciation for and a development of analytical skills. Written communication was also developed.
This course improved my writing skills and reading comprehension greatly.
I learned a lot about writing academic papers in addition to political philosophy. The feedback I got on my writing was incredibly beneficial.
Learned about different political philosophers, different versions of government. Learned to read lots of books in a very short time!

- better understanding of the development of Western political philosophy
- improved argumentative writing skills
I learned how to better relate different philosophers, while also learning the different forms of government that have been proposed throughout the history of man.

This course taught me to get through massive readings with efficiency, and then to use my notes on those readings to create pointed arguments in long papers, both of which are skills I needed to develop further. I felt like the feedback I got in class helped me to learn about this, and I really liked the subjects that we covered each week.
good overview of political philosophy

Learnt how to read challenging texts and pick out arguments and theological strands that I could compare across thinkers. 
Taught me how to tackle bigger, abstract questions such as "who should rule" and "what is justice".
Learnt to formulate my own analytical arguments and how to effectively compare and contrast thinkers within an essay.
I learned a broader and deeper understanding of the philosophers in the course, as well as how to read their works.

Reading material form ancient philosophers such as Plato and Aristotle
Connecting information from different political philosophers
Being able to read material with a purpose
A good overview of the most important authors in political philosophy, and better writing skills.
Read the major works of Western political philosophy, so now I can casually drop Aristotle and Rousseau in my daily conversations.

I have a general understanding of political philosophy starting from Plato and Socrates, and I gained insights into our own government and whether it's structure is optimal. This class helped me improve my ability to read philosophical texts, understand them and their context, and construct my own arguments.
I greatly improved my reading comprehension of philosophical texts.

I really enjoyed the readings.I hope the lectures could be more organized and informative. I don't think I got much away from the lectures. They seem to be all over the place. I hope there could be main arguments to analyze each lecture.
Lectures are boring and useless (at best), but section was a great way to cover the concepts themselves.

The course is well structured, and Professor Landemore clearly wanted everyone to learn. The first half of the class involved a lot of in class discussions, which were painful and essentially useless given that college freshman have limited experience and insight into these topics, but after doing a midterm feedback, she limited those and began really diving into some of the most engaging ideas in the course.

She did a good job at making this not a class in politics, but a class in philosophy, which was one my main worries going in.

One weakness was relating authors well to each other, for instance, relating Rousseau to the Federalists is a very interesting topic but was only scratched at the surface level.

A Political Philosophy survey course at Yale University should incorporate non-Western texts!!! It would enrich the experience for everyone if voices from myriad philosophical traditions were brought together in conversation. It needlessly narrows our perspectives to read only Western authors. Many of the Western authors we read were interesting; however, these authors' treatment of issues of race and gender ranged from inadequate to appalling. In what I'm guessing is a minor improvement over previous years, we did read W.E.B. Du Bois and Hannah Arendt at the end of the semester.
The course is strong in how it manages to bring a variety of perspectives together, but at times, I felt like the lectures could be a bit dry or disorganized.

The strength and weakness of this course is in its breadth. We covered so much, but it was often too hard to think too long about a book because we had to move on to the next one. I think it would be best to try to cut one or two authors, so that we can spend a little longer on some of the authors that had a heavier emphasis in the course, such as Rousseau and Tocqueville.
Moreover, I found that the preparation for the final was unreasonable. We were given thirteen essay prompts and had to prepare for all of them. I would much rather have had a topic to study, such as freedom and democracy, and then come to the final without knowing the prompts. Instead, it felt like I was supposed to spend tens of hours writing 13 essays, memorizing them, and then regurgitating them on the final. The actual final was not too bad, but again, it just felt like I was regurgitating what I had already learned. Otherwise, I would have preferred a longer, term paper, such as a 10 pager comparing two authors about a specific topic.

The strengths of this course are the materials. The lesson plan itself has a lot of potential, but the execution is poor on almost every front. To begin with, we try to tackle too much in too little a time. This complaint will sound like that of a lazy undergraduate, but I would prefer more REAL work that allows us to engage with the material than hollow skimmings of some of the greatest pieces of literature, political philosophy and thought. As a result, must people did not read. When we did read, it was so unguided it felt almost futile. Lectures helped very little, and they lagged in any sort of staunch analysis aside from a brief overview. The teacher clearly knew her information and cared about it, but the curriculum as well as her philosophy that we should be "thrown in" to every text doomed her class from the start. Discussion sections were one of the few bright spots, aside from the actual readings. My TF, Naomi, was not always the most outwardly helpful, but she would always assist students when in need. She obviously cared about our understanding of the material and wanted us to love the works as much as she did, which I appreciated.
Terrible structure, and barely any feedback for improvement

I got a lot out of having a small section (6 people) because it required us to be engaged in the texts and the course. Also, if something wasn't clear going into section, the intimacy of the group led to our lack of understanding being addressed before the end of the section. However, in my opinion many of the texts we read brought up few relevant points but were highly challenging to read. Because of this, the course would have been more effective if we read more 20th or 21st century texts.

The TAs of this course were certainly a strength because of how knowledgeable they were and also because of how involved Professor Landemore asked them to be in this class. Professor's Landemore's lectures were also a strength because although we were given a lot to read for a class, those lectures really focused on the essential points of larger readings. I always left class with a better understanding of the readings than when I started. 


This course certainly did cover a lot of material and sometimes I wished we were assigned a little more filtered version of these important points than having to read large passages of books that we only talked about for specific chapters.

Really good selection of material, some well known, but others not, which allows you to get a broader conception of the field at large. Pace was good and reading was substantial, but not overbearing. Lectures could have provided a little more analysis, though.

The sections are great for discussing in more detail and professor landemore does a good job of giving the readings context and discussing their main points in class. 


I thought that there could have been more comparative (between authors) work throughout the semeseter
I think the strength of the class are the books and the discussion sections. The books really help us understand how the ideas behind the current system of government in America developed over time.

Strengths: The TA's, posted powerpoint slides

Weaknesses: There are a lot of assigned readings that are barely touched upon or covered. Might make you wonder why you did it in the first place
Good layout for writing section.

Readings were important, but Prof. Landemore could have selected better excerpts as sometimes huge parts seemed irrelevant to the question she wanted us to think about. Sections were great, but lectures were not particularly interesting or helpful for the type of writing and ideas we were expected to generate.

Strengths: Readings, professor
Weakness: Some rushed lectures

This course provides a great in-depth introduction to the philosophical teachings that every student should know to help them understand the formation of modern politics. There is a lot of material to cover and it seems overbearing at times, but this is just in the nature of the course and should not necessarily be considered a weakness. The course covers not only politics and philosophy, but sociology as well, allowing students to better identify with and become more interested in the material.
Too much reading, very difficult to actually do it all which is a shame.

The course is an /intro/ the political philosophy, and it delivers to that name. It truly is an introductory course that gives you exposure to all of these important texts, but the course moves to fast and covers so much that other than reading the texts on your own, your greatest analytical moments happen in section, which is only 50 minutes a week. The lectures are great for cultural context and understanding main themes, but it is hard to fully feel like you understand and have engaged enough with an author or text, because you quickly have to move on.

This class is really well done! The lectures go over the important aspects of all the readings, and then section is used to synthesize your own views and hear others on the texts. Readings are heavy, but they of course have to be. Improvements? Maybe less in class discussion (because that's what sections are for!).
the lecture does not give a clear summary or guideline for reading the text.

Strengths: interesting material, wide variety of texts, interestig discussion sections
Weaknesses: lecture speed too fast, occasionally a greater summary of each reading was needed

Strengths:
- Study of works across human history 
- Understandinng of important ideas that pop up time and time again throughout history 

Weaknesses:
- Slightly too many works studied
This class involves a lot of reading and it is difficult to fully understand and follow along in section if the readings are not finished. It was definitely more of a time commitment than expected.
Prof didn't go in depth enough, the lectures were very vague, there were too many books assigned which didn't allow complete understanding/engagement of the authors texts.

I felt like not having access to lecture notes in the beginning of the class did not help me, and I often was too busy trying to scramble to get things down that I couldn't really synthesize my thoughts. I also felt that in-class discussions were scattered, and I did not benefit any greater from them than I would have if that time had been spent instead listening to the lecture.
overall very well taught

This course contains fascinating material and really important questions that are not only challenging to answer but also essential to the intellectual debates within political thought. It is a very good survey course for providing you with the basic analytical skills necessary for further studies in political philosophy and also introduces you to the core texts within this subject. 

However, the reading load is quite heavy and the pace of the course means that often there is not enough time to really explore all the thinkers equally and to extract as much as possible from each text. Especially in section, it would be helpful to have more time to debate the questions at hand.
I thought that discussion sections were helpful, as were lectures, but I did not like the activities and discussions during lecture time.

Strengths:
Diversity of readings
Common theme throughout course
PowerPoint based

Weaknesses:
Seminars lacked diversity in instruction

There were a good amount of readings. Slides were very organized and lectures were easy to follow but still very thought-provoking. Essay questions could have been broader and I wish we could've written about authors in the later sessions of the course. Could have had less class discussions.
Better TFs who grade more consistently.
Strength is that the course stuck closely to its objectives - who should rule, etc. I found the lectures uninspiring and sorely lacking in

A strength of this course was that it covered a lot of material in one semester, giving a very good overview of the subject. A weakness is that sometimes the lectures varied in their relevance to the reading or were skewed towards one opinion. Also, people relied on summaries of the texts from the lectures instead of actually doing the readings themselves. I think that the discussion sections were another strength of this course because they allowed us to read the text more closely and hear different opinions.
Strengths are the in-depth sections and interesting readings. Weaknesses are seeming lack of focus and direction in lectures, which makes it hard to tell what we're trying to take away.
I am a little bit hesitant. I did not get much from the lectures and I feel I would learn as much just by reading on my own.

Great class to learn the great books of political philosophy. You'll understand government and its design much clearer and gives a lens on how we got from Athens to Europe to the American Constitution (and their benefits and critiques). The workload isn't too hard, just a few papers and a final.
I would recommend it if you're dying to read the authors on the syllabus. Otherwise, think very carefully before signing up for this one; your interests may well be better served elsewhere.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in the topic, and I'm sure that some of the problem will improve as Professor Landemore keeps teaching. She clearly cares a lot about her students and the class and puts in a lot of effort to make it as enjoyable as possible.

As it stands today, I would not recommend this course. It is too ambitious for its own good in that we read so many authors that you cannot fully process each book. If you are really interested in political philosophy, then you should consider DS (if youre a first-year). I took this as a sophomore, and I ultimately regretted it. Expect to spend five hours a week (at the bare minimum) on readings, and then much more on weeks with papers. But then again, I did learn a lot about different political theorists.
I would recommend the course ONLY IF it was restructured, with a possible decrease in workload and a true curriculum aside from just reading texts.
Its a lot of reading, and i don't know if i would take it again. Took Writing intensive and did not improve my writing at all. Cool readings, bad class
Final is straight forward and the work isn't too bad.
Only if they were familiar with the level of difficulty of reading philosophical texts.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student, however I would particularly recommend this course as a writing credit so that you can receive feedback on your drafts before you turn in your final papers to be graded. I found that the expectations of writing were a little unclear at times, and so the feedback from my TAs really helped develop my writing and make sure that I was turning in work that was consistent with the expectations of the course.

Definitely would recommend this course to any student as it really gets you to think a lot deeper about political theory, but also many social issues and your own life in general. Well rounded course.
I would recommend the course for anyone interested in doing some of this reading and writing.
I would definitely recommend this class to another student even if they are only remotely interested in the subject.

If you take this course, you will get exactly what you expect: a survey knowledge of some basic political philosophers.
There aren't that many assignments in this class. There are upsides and downsides to that, the downside being that you don't have a lot of opportunities to impact your grade, but the upside being that there isn't that much work in the course.
Definitely the grading standards could be clarified; very difficult to know what you got.
Yes, good foundation
Yes. An important foundation for Political Philosophy and Political Science.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student that has enough time to dedicate to it. Students that do not spend as much time with the reading or that cannot take the time to truly analyze the material and form their own opinions will not find themselves getting nearly as much out of it as those that do. This is not only in a purely academic sense, but in a personal one - the ideas that students grapple with throughout the course can help them reflect on their own opinions and determine why they have them (whether because they truly believe in them, or because they have been influenced to believe that they should).
Yes
Good course if you don't mind reading a lot.Professor Landemore is great though.

I would recommend it to someone who has never read the texts of political philosophy. I hadn't read any Aristotle or Plato before coming in, and I found the class to be really insightful and valuable. Some of my classmates who already had a good knowledge of the texts found the class to be (understandably) redundant. The course really is what you make of it -- you can read each book and feel very engaged with each author's ideas or you can read none at all and then read one book for your midterm and finals essay and cram sparknotes to get main ideas for the final exam. I wouldn't recommend the latter, of course, but I know some people who have succeeded in doing this.
No I would not unless Bryan Garsten is teaching it.

Great intro phil course! Take it if you want to read the best of the best and expand your base of essential knowledge. Landemore is a great lecturer and her slides are amazing to learn from and study off of. You'll write basic phil papers and get good feedback too.

Yes, I would recommend this course for anyone interested in political science and/or an introduction to western philosophy. The readings, lectures, and discussion sections are very interesting, but be prepared for a pretty large amount of reading and if youre in a writing intensive section, lots of writing. Lecture speed was one issue with the course, so be prepared to write fast to keep up with the lectures.

A good introduction to the field of political philosophy. Professor Landemore's lectures are interesting and engaging. Take this course as long as you are prepared to put in the work in terms of reading (because you will have new works weekly and some of them are quite lengthy).

I think it is worthwhile to read and understand most if not all the books assigned in this course and for that reason I would recommend the course. I didn't think lectures were very interesting and I didn't feel like lecture or section, until the last couple of weeks and reading period, helped me gain a better understanding of the philosophies we were reading.
Yes. The writing intensive course was interesting and allowed for in-depth analysis of topics chosen by the student.
Yes, as long as it's understood that the readings during shopping week are nothing like the rest of the class. It is more of a time commitment than I first thought.

Maybe. If they are willing to work a ton and have lots of time to do the readings, then I would recommend this course because it is really interesting. If they don't have tons of spare time, I would not recommend it.
Yes, it is very interesting and a foundation for all political thought.

I would caution other students to only take this course if they are particularly interested in getting a wide view of political theory and if they are willing to have their great hinge solely on their performance on a few essays. If that is the experience they are looking for, I think this class does a good job of accomplishing that.
yes would recommend

I would recommend this course based on the texts taught and the interesting questions students are expected to tackle. However, the pace of the course means that a lot of the learning falls on the student and there is not necessarily a lot of support, especially for the student who does not have a lot of prior experience with writing about philosophy.
Yes, I thought it was an effective overview of  political thinking.
Yes, for any student in political science or philosophy this course provides a great overview of important political themes throughout history
Absolutely!!
I would recommend it more highly with a professor other than Landemore. She's not horrible, but not super engaging.

No if it is still taught by Professor Landemore. The lectures were disappointing, especially the first few ones (on the ancients like plato and socrates), albeit it got slightly better at the end. The texts on the list are absolutely wonderful, and I appreciate that Professor Landemore chose them intentionally, but I felt that the lectures (which was the main way that we were introduced to the text) hardly did them justice. There was so much knowledge to be mined from them, but hardly any of that I obtained through this course. I often found the official lessons so lacking that I mostly relied on myself, classmates or other classes that covered the same texts. Because of that, I think that if you are looking for an intellectual challenge, a course with this professor is not really the place to get it. Unless you are lucky enough to find good classmates AND a good teaching fellow (choose wisely). Only a few lectures I found good, which were conducted by teaching assistants.

I would recommend this class to another student because I think it gives a very good and important introduction to the philosophy that can help explain human nature and our current governmental institutions.
Yes, if they are willing to do many readings.
